{
  "article_text": [
    "the quantum kicked rotor  @xcite consists of a massive quantum particle moving freely on a circumference and periodically kicked by a cosine pulse that modifies its angular momentum .",
    "this kind of dynamics is generated by the following time - dependent singular hamiltonian @xmath0 where @xmath1 is a coupling constant with the dimension of an action , @xmath2 is the momentum of inertia and @xmath3 the kicking period .",
    "the classical and quantum kicked rotors have been deeply investigated in connection with classical chaos and its signature in quantum systems  @xcite and have also been physically implemented  @xcite .",
    "further interest in this model came from the possibility of being used to investigate the anderson localization  @xcite and transition from the metallic to the insulating regime  @xcite .",
    "the quantum kicked rotor localizes the system in angular momentum space when the period @xmath4 , with irrational @xmath5 , while in the anderson model an electron is localized on a @xmath6-dimensional lattice in presence of spatial noise .",
    "there exists a procedure to map the kicked rotor into an anderson localization model and vice versa  @xcite .",
    "there exists another model , known as quantum linear kicked rotor  @xcite , also known as _ maryland model _",
    ", where the kinetic term in the hamiltonian is taken to be linear in angular momentum , @xmath7 this model has the advantage of being analytically solvable and can also be mapped into a model exhibiting anderson localization when @xmath8 , with irrational @xmath5  @xcite .    in the following",
    ", we shall consider the scenario in which the quantum linear kicked rotor is in contact with an external environment of classical type whose presence is effectively taken into account by treating the kick strengths as stochastic variables .",
    "the ensuing decoherence weakens the destructive quantum interferences responsible for the angular momentum localization leading to a diffusive behaviour exhibited by the momentum variance increasing with the square root of time  @xcite .",
    "we shall focus upon the kick strengths forming a discrete - time markov process with varying degree of memory between the realization of the stochastic kick strength at a certain time and the successive one .",
    "the resulting dynamics is described by a discrete family of completely positive maps that compose as a semigroup in absence of memory and are otherwise connected by intertwining maps that are not completely positive as witnessed by the non - monotonic behaviour of the hilbert - schmidt norm .",
    "this discrete - time dissipative quantum process appears to be non - markovian according to the approach to non - markovianity through the absence of divisibility  @xcite  @xcite ( for another approach to non - markoviaity see  @xcite and  @xcite ) .",
    "furthermore , in the present model it can be proved that memory effects make the intertwining maps not even positive .",
    "as outlined in the introduction , we shall focus upon the following hamiltonian @xmath9 where the @xmath10 are stochastic variables taking values in @xmath11 that perturb the otherwise constant kick strength at discrete times @xmath12 ; we shall take them to form a one - step markov process @xmath13 that we will specify later on .    in the following",
    ", we shall frequently use angle representation ( for sake of simplicity @xmath14 ) , where @xmath15 and the operator @xmath16 has eigenvectors @xmath17    because of the dirac delta , the time - evolutor from @xmath18 and @xmath19 is given by the following unitary operator on the hilbert space @xmath20,{\\rm d}\\theta)$ ] of the system : @xmath21 let us consider an initial state , namely a density matrix @xmath22 acting on @xmath23 ; the state @xmath24 at discrete time @xmath25 is thus obtained as @xmath26 using that @xmath27 one rewrites @xmath28 the variance of the angular momentum with respect to a time - evolving state initially localized in momentum space is a measure of how much the latter spreads . in the heisenberg picture",
    "@xmath29 setting @xmath30 and choosing as initial state the zero - angular momentum eigenstate @xmath31 of @xmath16 , one gets @xmath32\\ . \\label{sm27}\\end{aligned}\\ ] ] as this result depends on the explicit realization of the stochastic process up to time @xmath25 , in order to get a physically testable quantity one has to average over all possible realizations .    before going to that , let us consider the case when the kick strengths are not stochastically perturbed , namely @xmath33 for all @xmath34 ; then , the variance is a bounded function of @xmath35 when @xmath8 with @xmath5 irrational , with corresponding localization , that is there is no spreading in angular momentum as illustrated in fig .",
    "[ im0 ] . on the other hand , fig .",
    "[ im0a ] shows the increasing of the angular momentum variance for @xmath36 .",
    "as function of @xmath37 for @xmath38 and @xmath39 without stochastic kicks.,scaledwidth=70.0% ]     as function of @xmath37 for @xmath38 and @xmath40 without stochastic kicks.,scaledwidth=70.0% ]    from now on , the attention will be focused on the case @xmath8 with @xmath5 irrational .",
    "as already stated , we take as @xmath13 a discrete @xmath6-step markov process with each @xmath10 taking the values @xmath41 with probabilities @xmath42 .",
    "the stochastic strengths are chosen in such a way that , at each tick of time of period @xmath3 , the rotor is kicked or not with equal probability .",
    "furthermore , the probability for the realization of the stochastic process @xmath43 will be denoted by @xmath44 of the form @xmath45 with transition coefficients @xmath46 for the value @xmath47 be followed by @xmath48 , given by @xmath49 so that the @xmath50 transition matrix @xmath51 $ ] reads @xmath52 the first contribution to the transition matrix represents a markov process with full memory , in the sense that only the first kick strength is stochastic and if it takes the value @xmath1 @xmath53 , it will keep it @xmath1 @xmath53 at all other times . on the other hand ,",
    "the second contribution to the transition matrix gives rise to a bernoulli process with no memory , that is successive kick strengths are independent of one another .",
    "therefore , by increasing @xmath54 from @xmath55 to @xmath6 one interpolates between a markov process with no memory and one with full memory .",
    "the form of the transition matrix is particularly simple and yields @xmath56 furthermore , the probability vector @xmath57 is left invariant by the transition matrix @xmath58 so that the markov process is stationary : @xmath59 the characteristic function of such a process reads @xmath60    we shall denote by @xmath61 the averages with respect to the probability distribution ; then , the first moments @xmath62 while the second moments @xmath63 can be computed as follows : suppose @xmath64 , then @xmath65 from the stationarity of the process  ( [ stationary ] ) and  ( [ tmn ] ) one gets @xmath66 then , the momentum variance with respect to the angular momentum eigenstate @xmath67 reads @xmath68\\ .",
    "\\label{sm31markov}\\end{aligned}\\ ] ] figure  [ imm1 ] shows a diffusive behaviour which tends to disappear as @xmath54 approaches @xmath6 .     as function of @xmath37 for the markov process with @xmath38 and @xmath39.,scaledwidth=70.0% ]    in the case of @xmath69 , with probability @xmath70 there are no kicks and with the same probability there are always kicks of same strength @xmath1 ; therefore , the full memory case corresponds to the deterministic maryland model ( divided by two as this is the probability for a process with kicks ) as showed in the following figure for irrational @xmath71 .",
    "as function of @xmath37 in the deterministic maryland model and in the stochastic markov model with with full memory : @xmath38 , @xmath39 and @xmath69.,scaledwidth=70.0% ]",
    "like for the physical variance , a physical time - evolution for the density matrix of the linear kicked rotor with stochastic kicks is obtained from  ( [ sm5 ] ) by averaging with respect to the realizations @xmath72 of the stochastic process up to time @xmath25 .",
    "the averaging process yields the following maps on the density matrices of the quantum linear kicked rotor : @xmath73=\\sum_{\\bar{x}_n\\in\\{0,1\\}^n } p(\\bar{x}_n)\\,\\prod_{j=1}^n\\hat{u}_{j\\tau}(x_j)\\,\\hat{\\rho}\\ , \\prod_{j=1}^n\\hat{u}^\\dag_{j\\tau}(x_j)\\ , \\label{sm32}\\ ] ] where the unitary operators @xmath74 are as in  ( [ sm4 ] ) and depend on the realization of the stochastic process at @xmath75 , @xmath76 is the probability distribution ( [ markov ] ) .",
    "the maps @xmath77 are unital and trace - preserving : @xmath78&=&\\sum_{\\bar{x}_n\\in\\{0,1\\}^n } p(\\bar{x}_n)\\,\\prod_{j=1}^n\\hat{u}_{j\\tau}(x_j)\\,1\\ , \\prod_{j=1}^n\\hat{u}^\\dag_{j\\tau}(x_j)=\\sum_{\\bar{x}_n\\in\\{0,1\\}^n } p(\\bar{x}_n)\\,=\\ , 1\\\\ \\nonumber { { { \\rm tr}}}(\\phi_n[\\hat{\\rho}])&=&\\sum_{\\bar{x}_n\\in\\{0,1\\}^n } p(\\bar{x}_n)\\,{{{\\rm tr}}}\\left[\\prod_{j=1}^n\\hat{u}_{j\\tau}(x_j)\\right]\\,\\hat{\\rho}\\ ,",
    "\\left[\\prod_{j=1}^n\\hat{u}^\\dag_{j\\tau}(x_j)\\right]=\\sum_{\\bar{x}_n\\in\\{0,1\\}^n } p(\\bar{x}_n)\\,{{{\\rm tr}}}(\\hat{\\rho})\\\\ \\label{trace0 } & = & \\,{{{\\rm tr}}}(\\hat{\\rho})\\ .\\end{aligned}\\ ] ]    [ rem1 ] the dynamical maps @xmath77 evolve any given initial density matrix into a density matrix at time @xmath25 ; indeed , because of the positivity of the probability measure , they are a convex combination of unitary actions and thus a ( generalized ) kraus - stinespring form of completely positive maps on the space of states  @xcite . therefore , they preserve the positivity not only of @xmath22 , but the composite maps @xmath79 also preserve the positivity of generic density matrices acting on the hilbert spaces @xmath80 , for all @xmath81 . this latter fact is essential for the physical consistency of the maps as dynamical maps ; indeed , one could always couple the quantum linear kicked rotor with an @xmath82-level system in such a way that the states of the coupled system evolve according to @xmath79 : if @xmath77 were not completely positive , one could always find an @xmath82 and an entangled initial state @xmath83 of the compound system such that @xmath84 $ ] develops for some @xmath35 negative eigenvalues then losing positivity and thus its physical interpretation as a state .    if the stochastic process @xmath85 consisted of independent identically distributed stochastic variables , then @xmath86 and @xmath87 , @xmath35 times , where @xmath88=\\sum_{x=0,1}\\,e^{-ik(1-x)\\cos\\hat{\\theta}}\\,e^{-i\\hat{p}\\tau}\\,\\hat{\\rho}\\ , e^{i\\hat{p}\\tau}\\,e^{ik(1-x)\\cos\\hat{\\theta}}\\ . \\label{sm46}\\ ] ] independence of @xmath89 means the absence of memory among realizations of the noise at different times which is reflected by the fact that the family of dynamical maps is a discrete semigroup : @xmath90 .",
    "the presence of memory between kicks at different times spoils the semigroup property , but one can still wonder whether there exist intertwining maps @xmath91 on the space of states such that @xmath92 so that the issue at stake is to invert maps as in  ( [ sm32 ] ) .",
    "let us introduce the real @xmath35-dimensional vectors @xmath93 , @xmath94 and denote by @xmath95 the scalar products of such vectors ; then , using  ( [ sm10 ] ) , one rewrites @xmath96&=&e^{-i\\hat{p}\\,n\\,\\tau}\\,\\psi_n[\\hat{\\rho}]\\,e^{i\\hat{p}\\,n\\,\\tau}\\\\ \\psi_n[\\hat{\\rho}]&=&\\sum_{\\bar{x}_n\\in\\{0,1\\}^n } p(\\bar{x}_n)\\,e^{-i\\langle\\bar{j}_n(\\bar{x}_{n})\\vert\\bar{\\nu}_{n}(\\hat{\\theta})\\rangle}\\,\\hat{\\rho}\\ , e^{i\\langle\\bar{j}_n(\\bar{x}_{n})\\vert\\bar{\\nu}_{n}(\\hat{\\theta})\\rangle}\\ . \\label{sm33a}\\end{aligned}\\ ] ] in order to find the inverse of the map @xmath97 , one can proceed as follows : from @xmath98\\vert\\theta_{2}\\rangle\\,=\\,\\langle\\theta_{1}\\vert\\hat{\\rho}\\vert\\theta_{2}\\rangle\\,\\sum_{\\bar{x}_n\\in\\{0,1\\}^n } p(\\bar{x}_n)\\ , e^{i\\langle\\bar{j}_n(\\bar{x}_{n})\\vert\\bar{\\nu}_{n}(\\theta_{2})-\\bar{\\nu}_{n}(\\theta_{1})\\rangle}\\ , \\label{sm67}\\ ] ] one can formally invert the expression , yielding @xmath99\\vert\\theta_{2}\\rangle } { \\sum_{\\bar{x}_n\\in\\{0,1\\}^n } p(\\bar{x}_n)\\,e^{-i\\langle\\bar{x}_{n}|\\bar{\\nu}_{n}(\\theta_{2})-\\bar{\\nu}_{n}(\\theta_{1})\\rangle}}\\ . \\label{sm68}\\ ] ] by means of a @xmath35-dimensional dirac delta @xmath100 used to represent the fraction , one can write the representation independent operator expression @xmath101\\ ,   e^{-i\\langle \\bar{i}_n+\\bar{v}_{n}\\vert\\bar{\\nu}_{n}(\\hat{\\theta})\\rangle}\\ , \\label{sm71}\\ ] ] where @xmath102 is the characteristic function of the probability distribution over the noise - realizations @xmath103 . therefore , the formal inverse of the map @xmath77 in  ( [ sm32 ] ) is the following linear map @xmath104 acting on the operators @xmath105 on @xmath106 , @xmath107=\\int \\frac{{\\rm d}\\bar{u}_{n}{\\rm d}\\bar{v}_{n}}{(2\\pi)^{n}}\\,\\frac{e^{i\\langle\\bar{v}_{n}\\vert\\bar{u}_{n}\\rangle}}{\\lambda_n(\\bar{u}_n)}\\ , e^{i\\langle \\bar{i}_{n}+\\bar{v}_{n}\\vert\\bar{\\nu}_{n}(\\hat{\\theta})\\rangle}\\,e^{i\\hat{p}\\,n\\,\\tau}\\,\\hat{x}\\,e^{-i\\hat{p}\\,n\\,\\tau}\\ , e^{-i\\langle \\bar{i}_{n}+\\bar{v}_{n}\\vert\\bar{\\nu}_{n}(\\hat{\\theta})\\rangle}\\ .\\ ] ] let @xmath108 be the fourier transform of the inverse of the characteristic function ; one rewrites @xmath109=\\int{\\rm d}\\bar{v}_n\\ , \\tilde{\\lambda}_n(\\bar{v}_n)\\,e^{i\\langle \\bar{i}_{n}+\\bar{v}_{n}\\vert\\bar{\\nu}_{n}(\\hat{\\theta})\\rangle } \\,e^{i\\hat{p}\\,n\\,\\tau}\\,\\hat{x}\\,e^{-i\\hat{p}\\,n\\,\\tau}\\,e^{-i\\langle \\bar{i}_{n}+\\bar{v}_{n}\\vert\\bar{\\nu}_{n}(\\hat{\\theta})\\rangle}\\ .\\ ] ] like  ( [ sm32 ] ) , the expression above resembles a continuous kraus - stinespring representation of a completely positive map ; however , unlike the fourier transform of the characteristic function @xmath102 which yields the probability distribution and is thus positive , @xmath110 need not be positive , whence @xmath104 and thus @xmath111 need not be completely positive .",
    "[ ncprem ] the fourier transform @xmath112 need not exist as a function .",
    "however , since it appears within an integration with respect to @xmath113 it can always be interpreted as a distribution over a suitable class of test functions .",
    "these integration functions immediately appear when computing quantities as @xmath114\\vert\\psi\\rangle=\\int{\\rm d}\\bar{v}_n\\ , \\tilde{\\lambda}_n(\\bar{v}_n)\\ , \\langle\\varphi\\vert\\hat{v}_n(\\bar{v}_n ) \\,e^{i\\hat{p}\\,n\\,\\tau}\\,\\hat{x}\\,e^{-i\\hat{p}\\,n\\,\\tau}\\ , \\hat{v}^\\dag_n(\\bar{v}_n)\\vert\\psi\\rangle\\ , \\ ] ] where the operators are as in  ( [ inverse1 ] ) , with suitable choices of vectors @xmath115 .",
    "notice that @xmath104 is unital and trace preserving , namely @xmath116&=&\\int{\\rm d}\\bar{v}_n\\ , \\tilde{\\lambda}_n(\\bar{v}_n)\\ , 1\\ , = \\",
    ", 1\\\\ \\nonumber { { { \\rm tr}}}(\\phi^{-1}_n[\\hat{\\rho}])&=&\\int{\\rm d}\\bar{v}_n\\ , \\tilde{\\lambda}_n(\\bar{v}_n)\\ , { { { \\rm tr}}}\\big(\\hat{v}_n(\\bar{v}_n ) \\,e^{i\\hat{p}\\,n\\,\\tau}\\,\\hat{\\rho}\\,e^{-i\\hat{p}\\,n\\,\\tau}\\ , \\hat{v}^\\dag_n(\\bar{v}_n)\\big)\\\\ \\label{trace } & = & \\int{\\rm d}\\bar{v}_n\\ , \\tilde{\\lambda}_n(\\bar{v}_n)\\ , { { { \\rm tr}}}(\\hat{\\rho})={{{\\rm tr}}}(\\hat{\\rho})\\ .\\end{aligned}\\ ] ]    in the case of a continuous - time family of completely positive maps @xmath117 , while markovianity is identified by the composition law @xmath118 a criterion of non - markovianity is taken to be the indivisibility of the one - parameter family of maps @xmath119  ( [ sm32 ] ) , namely the absence of completely positive intertwining maps @xmath120 such that @xmath121 the absence of completely positive intertwining maps can be witnessed by the non - monotonic behavior of quantities that , under completely positive maps , would either be always non - decreasing or non - increasing . consider a function @xmath122 on the space of states which is monotonically non - increasing under completely positive maps @xmath123 , that is @xmath124 .",
    "since the maps @xmath119 are completely positive , it follows that @xmath125 for all @xmath126 ; however , if @xmath120 is not completely positive , then @xmath127 need not be smaller than @xmath128 and @xmath129 may then increase in the time - interval @xmath130 $ ] ( see  @xcite for an updated review ) .    in the following we study the discrete - time occurrence of such a non - markovianity criterion .",
    "in the continuous case , several witnesses of non - markovianiy have been proposed  @xcite-@xcite based on the absence of monotonic behaviour . in the following , we will consider the hilbert - schmidt norm on the space of bounded operators on @xmath106 , @xmath131 all unital completely positive maps @xmath123 , that is such that @xmath132=1 $ ] , satisfy the so - called schwartz - positivity , namely @xmath133\\geq ( \\psi[x])^\\dag\\psi[x]\\ ] ] for all operators @xmath105 on @xmath106 . indeed , @xmath123 completely positive means that @xmath134 is positive ; then , setting @xmath135 , on the positive operator on @xmath136 @xmath137 one gets @xmath138 & -(\\psi[\\hat{x}])^{\\dagger}\\cr             -\\psi[\\hat{x } ]   &       1 \\end{pmatrix}\\,\\geq\\,0\\ .\\ ] ] it then follows that , for all @xmath139 , @xmath140)^\\dag\\right ) \\begin{pmatrix } \\psi[\\hat{x}^\\dagger\\hat{x } ] & -\\psi[\\hat{x}^\\dag]\\\\             -\\psi[\\hat{x } ]   &       1 \\end{pmatrix } \\begin{pmatrix }    \\psi[x]|\\varphi\\rangle \\end{pmatrix } = \\langle\\varphi\\vert\\psi[\\hat{x}^\\dag\\hat{x}]-(\\psi[\\hat{x}])^\\dag\\psi[\\hat{x}]\\vert\\varphi\\rangle\\ge0\\ .\\ ] ] from schwartz - positivity it follows that the hilbert - schmidt norm must decrease under completely positive unital and trace preserving maps ; indeed , @xmath141\\|^2_{hs}={{{\\rm",
    "tr}}}\\big((\\psi[\\hat{x}])^\\dag\\psi[\\hat{x}]\\big)\\leq{{{\\rm tr}}}\\big(\\psi[\\hat{x}^\\dag\\hat{x}]\\big)={{{\\rm tr}}}\\big(\\hat{x}^\\dag\\hat{x}\\big ) = \\|\\hat{x}\\|^2_{hs}\\ .\\ ] ] let us now consider the hilbert - schmidt norm of a density matrix @xmath142 $ ] that evolves in time according to the discrete family of dynamical maps @xmath77 in  ( [ sm32 ] ) that compose as in  ( [ intertwining ] ) . if @xmath91 were completely positive , then , because of the previous argument @xmath143 .",
    "indeed , @xmath144 is unital and trace preserving for such are @xmath77 and @xmath145 as follows from  ( [ unital0 ] ) ,  ( [ trace0 ] ) and  ( [ unital ] ) ,  ( [ trace ] ) .    a sufficiently explicit expression for the hilbert - schmidt norm @xmath146 that is amenable to numerical investigations is readily achieved . using  ( [ sm33 ] ) , one explicitly finds @xmath147\\|^2_{hs}={{{\\rm tr}}}\\big(\\psi^2_n[\\hat{\\rho}]\\big)\\\\ \\label{app1 } & & = \\sum_{\\bar{x}_n,\\bar{y}_n\\in\\{0,1\\}^n}\\,p(\\bar{x}_n)\\,p(\\bar{y}_n)\\ , { { { \\rm tr}}}\\left(\\hat{\\rho}\\,e^{i\\langle\\bar{x}_n-\\bar{y}_n\\vert\\bar{\\nu}_n(\\hat{\\theta})\\rangle}\\,\\hat{\\rho}\\ , e^{-i\\langle\\bar{x}_n-\\bar{y}_n\\vert\\bar{\\nu}_n(\\hat{\\theta})\\rangle}\\right)\\ .\\end{aligned}\\ ] ] by going to the angle representation , whereby @xmath148 , one expresses the hilbert - schmidt norm in terms of the probability distribution characteristic function : @xmath149\\|^2_{hs}= \\int_0^{2\\pi}{\\rm d}\\theta_1\\,\\int_0^{2\\pi}{\\rm d}\\theta_2\\,|\\langle\\theta_1\\vert\\hat{\\rho}\\vert\\theta_2\\rangle|^2\\ , \\big|\\lambda\\big(\\bar{\\nu}_n(\\theta_1)-\\bar{\\nu}_n(\\theta_2)\\big)\\big|^2\\ .\\ ] ] in the case of the markov process one uses  ( [ charfunctmarkov ] ) with @xmath150    figure @xmath151 shows various time behaviours of the hilbert - schmidt norm for an initial momentum eigen - projector @xmath152 : in absence of memory ( @xmath153 ) , the hilbert - schmidt distance behaves monotonically , whereas the higher is @xmath54 , the higher is the memory in the process , the more it oscillates .",
    "\\|^2_{hs}$ ] for markovian kicks : @xmath38 and @xmath154.,scaledwidth=70.0% ]    with respect to definition of non - markovianity corresponding to the absence of intertwining completely positive maps , the above result is an evidence of the fact that this choice makes sense also when there are no generators for the dynamics .",
    "moreover , in the present case the non - markovianity witness is the hilbert - schmidt norm while in  @xcite is the fidelity and in  @xcite the relative entropy of entanglement .",
    "this is due to the occurring maps being not only trace - preserving , but also unital .      from the previous numerical evidence , some of the maps @xmath91 can not be @xmath155-positive , for instance @xmath156 can not be positive , and thus @xmath157 can not be completely positive . in this section ,",
    "we address the properties of @xmath158 in more detail : namely , we also consider the problem of its positivity as a linear map , that is whether @xmath159\\geq 0 $ ] on all projectors @xmath160 on @xmath106 .",
    "we set @xmath161 . by means of  ( [ sm33 ] ) with @xmath162 , of  ( [ inverse1 ] ) and of the fact that @xmath163 with @xmath164 one finds @xmath165= \\sum_{x_{1,2}\\in\\{0,1\\}}p(x_1,x_2)\\ , \\int{\\rm d}u{\\rm d}v\\,\\frac{e^{iuv}}{2\\pi\\lambda_1(u)}\\ , e(x_1,x_2,v,\\hat{\\theta})\\,e^{-i\\hat{p}\\tau}\\,\\rho\\ , e^{i\\hat{p}\\tau}\\,e^\\dag(x_1,x_2,v,\\hat{\\theta})\\\\ \\label{gamma2 } & & \\hskip -.5 cm e(x_1,x_2,v,\\hat{\\theta})=e^{ik(x_{1}+v)\\cos(\\hat{\\theta}-\\tau)}e^{-ik(1-x_{2})\\cos\\hat\\theta}.\\end{aligned}\\ ] ] in the angle representation where @xmath166 , @xmath167= \\int_0^{2\\pi}{\\rm d}\\theta_1\\int_0^{2\\pi}{\\rm d}\\theta_2\\,e^{ik(\\cos\\theta_2-\\cos\\theta_1)}\\ , g(\\theta_1,\\theta_2)\\ , \\vert\\theta_1\\rangle\\langle\\theta_1\\vert\\,e^{-i\\hat{p}\\tau}\\,\\rho\\ , e^{i\\hat{p}\\tau}\\,\\vert\\theta_2\\rangle\\langle\\theta_2\\vert\\\\ & & \\hskip -.5 cm g(\\theta_1,\\theta_2)=\\frac{\\lambda_2\\big(k[\\cos(\\theta_2-\\tau)-\\cos(\\theta_1-\\tau)],k[\\cos\\theta_2-\\cos\\theta_1]\\big ) } { \\lambda_1\\big(k[\\cos(\\theta_2-\\tau)-\\cos(\\theta_1-\\tau)]\\big)}\\ . \\label{gamma4}\\end{aligned}\\ ] ] let @xmath22 be the following pure state projection @xmath168&=&\\frac{1}{2\\pi } \\int_0^{2\\pi}{\\rm d}\\theta_1\\int_0^{2\\pi}{\\rm d}\\theta_2\\ , g(\\theta_1,\\theta_2)\\ , \\vert\\theta_1\\rangle\\langle\\theta_2\\vert .\\end{aligned}\\ ] ] let then @xmath169 be a not normalized vector , with @xmath170}(\\theta)\\ , \\quad j=1,2\\ ] ] the characteristic functions of intervals around @xmath171 , @xmath172 , of size @xmath173 . then one considers the mean value @xmath174\\vert\\varphi\\rangle = i_1(\\varepsilon)+i_2(\\varepsilon)-i_{12}(\\varepsilon ) -i_{21}(\\varepsilon)\\quad\\hbox{where}\\\\ \\nonumber\\\\ \\label{positivity2a } i_1(\\varepsilon)&=&\\frac{1}{\\varepsilon^2 } \\int_{\\bar{\\theta}_1-\\varepsilon/2}^{\\bar{\\theta}_1+\\varepsilon/2}{\\rm d}\\theta_1\\int_{\\bar{\\theta}_1-\\varepsilon/2}^{\\bar{\\theta}_1+\\varepsilon/2}{\\rm d}\\theta_2\\ , g(\\theta_1,\\theta_2)\\\\ \\nonumber\\\\ \\label{positivity2b } i_2(\\varepsilon)&=&\\frac{1}{\\varepsilon^2 } \\int_{\\bar{\\theta}_2-\\varepsilon/2}^{\\bar{\\theta}_2+\\varepsilon/2}{\\rm d}\\theta_1 \\int_{\\bar{\\theta}_2-\\varepsilon/2}^{\\bar{\\theta}_2+\\varepsilon/2}{\\rm d}\\theta_2\\ , g(\\theta_1,\\theta_2)\\\\ \\nonumber\\\\ \\label{positivity2c } i_{12}(\\varepsilon)&= & \\frac{1}{\\varepsilon^2 } \\int_{\\bar{\\theta}_1-\\varepsilon/2}^{\\bar{\\theta}_1+\\varepsilon/2}{\\rm d}\\theta_1\\int_{\\bar{\\theta}_2-\\varepsilon/2}^{\\bar{\\theta}_2+\\varepsilon/2}{\\rm d}\\theta_2\\ ,",
    "g(\\theta_1,\\theta_2)\\\\ \\nonumber\\\\ \\label{positivity2d } i_{21}(\\varepsilon)&=&\\frac{1}{\\varepsilon^2}\\int_{\\bar{\\theta}_2-\\varepsilon/2}^{\\bar{\\theta}_2+\\varepsilon/2}{\\rm d}\\theta_1 \\int_{\\bar{\\theta}_1-\\varepsilon/2}^{\\bar{\\theta}_1+\\varepsilon/2}{\\rm d}\\theta_2\\ , g(\\theta_1,\\theta_2)\\ .\\end{aligned}\\ ] ] by letting @xmath175 one gets @xmath176 using  ( [ charfunctmarkov ] ) , the quantity @xmath177 between parenthesis reads @xmath178    for a suitable choice of angles @xmath179 , the quantity @xmath177 can become strictly larger than @xmath155 as showed in fig .",
    "@xmath180 , the positive and negative peaks correspond to zeroes of the denominator in the above expressions .",
    "therefore , the quantity @xmath181 in  ( [ nonppositivity ] ) becomes negative showing that the intertwining map , besides not being completely positive , is not even a positive map . in the absence of memory , that is when @xmath153 , the function @xmath181 is instead positive , as it must be .",
    "[ remfinal ] the functions in  ( [ positivity1 ] ) tend to dirac deltas when @xmath175 and thus exit from the hilbert space @xmath106 ; however , because of the continuity of the functions entering the integral defining @xmath182 in  ( [ positivity2 ] ) , the previous limit ensures that one can always find a suitably small , but finite @xmath183 such that @xmath184 .",
    ": @xmath185\\times[0;2\\pi]\\to\\mathbb{r}$ ] for markovian kicks : @xmath186 , @xmath38 and @xmath154.,scaledwidth=70.0% ]",
    "we studied a stochastic version of the quantum linear kicked rotor , obtained by letting the kick strengths become a discrete markov process .",
    "the dynamics becomes a dissipative quantum process consisting of a discrete family of completely positive maps . in case of absence of memory ,",
    "when the markov process becomes of bernoulli type , it has been shown that these maps compose as a discrete semigroup .",
    "on the other hand , when memory effects are present , non - markovianity is witnessed by the non monotonic behaviour of the hilbert - schmidt norm .",
    "the origin of this behaviour is to be found in the fact that the intertwining maps connecting completely positive maps at different ticks of time are trace - preserving but not completely positive , linking non - markovianity to non - divisibility ( in a discrete sense in the present case ) .",
    "a more detailed study of the intertwining maps shows that they are not even positive ."
  ],
  "abstract_text": [
    "<S> the so - called maryland model is a linear version of the quantum kicked rotor ; it exhibits anderson localization in momentum space . by turning the kicks into a markovian stochastic process , </S>",
    "<S> the dynamics becomes a dissipative quantum process described by a discrete family of completely positive maps that allows to explicitly study the relation between divisibility of the maps and the degree of memory of the process . </S>"
  ]
}
